title: Wanderer zwischen den politischen Mächten: Pater Nikolaus von Lutterotti O.S.B. (1892–1955) und die Abtei Grüssau in Niederschlesien (review)
abstract: Wanderer zwischen den politischen Machten: Pater Nikolaus von Lutterotti O.S.B. (1892-1955) und die Abtei Grussau in Niederschlesien. By Inge Steinstraser. [Forschungen und Quellen zur Kirchen- und Kulturgeschichte Ostdeutschlands, Band 4L] (Cologne: Bohlau Verlag. 2009- Pp. xvi, 685. euro64,90. ISBN 978-3-412-20429-7.) In this revised dissertation, Inge Steinstraser illustrates the tension between Christian universalism and nationalism. During the tumultuous history of twentieth-century Central Europe, the Church, for Nikolaus von Lutterotti, O.S.B. , constituted the one constant identity in a world in which national identities proved unstable. The von Lutterotti family hailed from Kaltem, one of Tyrol's southernmost German-speaking towns, but identified itself as Austrian, even after Italy gained South Tyrol. Nonetheless, the Lutterottis opted to accept Italian citizenship. By this time, Nikolaus had already joined the Benedictine Emmaus Abbey in Prague. Because of the strident pan-Germanism of Abbot Alban Schachleiter- who later became an ardent Nazi supporter- the monks were forced to leave Prague.The war's end transformed Lutterotti's identity, both as a Tyrolean and as a member of the Emaus community. Monks from Emmaus established a new abbey at Grussau in Silesia. With few resources and great personal engagement, the monks restored the facilities, which had housed Cistercian monks until the secularization of the nineteenth century. In addition to Lutterotti's pastoral and conventual responsibilities, he pursued archival studies, and published both popular and scholarly art history articles relating to the abbey. Additionally, Lutterotti supervised the restoration of the abbey. The Nazi years proved difficult for the abbey, not only because of the increasing antireligious repression. As Brigitte Lob already discussed in her Albert Schmitt OSB-sein kirchenpolitisches Handeln in der Weimarer Republik und im Dritten Reich (Koln, 2000), Schmitt, the abbot of Grussau, initially shared the enthusiasm of his brother abbots Ildefons Herwegen at Maria Laach and Schachleiter for the new regime. Although never as ardent or prominent as Schachleiter, Schmitt also did not share Herwegen's eventual realization of the regime's nature. While Steinstraser could have developed Lutterotti's views further, she judiciously analyzes the sparse evidence to show that Lutterotti rejected the abbot's political views. Lutterotti's rejection of the Nazis led him to withdraw an application for German citizenship. In postwar homilies, Lutterotti placed blame for his flock's suffering squarely on the Nazi regime and its supporters. …

motivations: The complex and tumultuous history of twentieth-century Central Europe highlights the tension between Christian universalism and nationalism, necessitating a deeper understanding of the role of the Church and individual identities during this period.

The life and experiences of Pater Nikolaus von Lutterotti O.S.B. offer a unique lens through which to examine the challenges faced by the Church and its members in navigating the shifting political landscape of the time.
objectives: To illustrate the tension between Christian universalism and nationalism through the life and experiences of Pater Nikolaus von Lutterotti O.S.B.
To examine the ways in which the Church and its members navigated the complex and often conflicting demands of national identity, politics, and faith during the twentieth century.
methods: Biographical analysis of Pater Nikolaus von Lutterotti O.S.B.'s life and experiences, drawing on archival studies and historical research.
Examination of the historical context in which Lutterotti lived and worked, including the rise of Nazi Germany and the impact of World War II on the Church and its members.
results: A nuanced understanding of the complex and often fraught relationship between the Church and national identity in twentieth-century Central Europe.

Insight into the ways in which individual members of the Church, such as Pater Nikolaus von Lutterotti O.S.B., navigated the challenges of this period and maintained their faith and identity in the face of adversity.

motivations: There is a need to understand the tension between Christian universalism and nationalism in the context of twentieth-century Central Europe.
The complex identity of Nikolaus von Lutterotti, a Benedictine monk, and his relationship with the Church and national identities during a politically tumultuous period is not well-explored.
objectives: Illustrate the tension between Christian universalism and nationalism through the life and experiences of Nikolaus von Lutterotti.
Analyze the impact of political changes on Lutterotti's identity and his role in the Church.
methods: Use archival studies and historical analysis to explore Lutterotti's life, his pastoral and conventual responsibilities, and his views on nationalism.
Examine Lutterotti's published articles and homilies to understand his political views and his relationship with the Church.
results: Provide a nuanced understanding of the tension between Christian universalism and nationalism in the context of twentieth-century Central Europe.

motivations: The tension between Christian universalism and nationalism in twentieth-century Central Europe created complex identity challenges for religious figures.
The unstable national identities and political upheavals of the era necessitated examination of how religious communities navigated these changes.
objectives: Illustrate the tension between Christian universalism and nationalism through the life of Pater Nikolaus von Lutterotti.
Examine how religious identity served as a constant in a world of shifting national boundaries and political regimes.
methods: Historical analysis of archival materials and documents related to Lutterotti and the Grüssau Abbey.
Examination of Lutterotti's writings, pastoral work, and responses to political changes from the Austrian Empire through Nazi Germany.
results: Demonstrates how Lutterotti maintained religious identity while rejecting Nazi ideology despite pressure from his abbot.
Reveals the complex negotiations between religious commitment and political pressures in twentieth-century Central Europe.
